history.content:
https://reslife.berkeley.edu/gpa-calculator/
________

Unfortunately, this does not answer my original question of which classes to include when calculating the GPA. I know *how* to calculate my GPA, just wondering which classes others advise to include in that calculation. 

For example, including the lower core classes like CS61 series, CS70, and EE16AB? Including CoE requirements like Math and Physics classes? Or just going by APR (upper div technicals and electives)?

________
For my grad apps, I used all the classes that started with "EE," "CS," or "EECS" in my calculation and did not use my math and science requirements in my GPA. There were no issues that were brought up with that, but I think I noted what I used in my calculation somewhere. I didn't *just* use my APR though; I think it's imperative that you include your lower divs.

________

That makes a ton of sense. Thanks for your response, especially given you've already gone through the process!

children.subject: The gpa calculator's not really relevant, since the question is about what to include in the EECS GPA

They do, I mentioned it as APR but it only includes upper division courses and electives (no CS 61 series, CS70, or EE16AB), and it feels a little weird to not include those core classes in a major GPA.
^I agree. I think it's important to include lower divs
Not sure if CoE has this, but for L&S CS on the academic progress report on calcentral the Major GPA is listed as the first item under the CS BA
My rationale was "only classes in the department" is a reasonable standard for "major GPA".
I excluded Physics when computing my major GPA for grad apps.
What I would do: consider all reasonable interpretations of major GPA and use the one that gets you the highest number.

history.content:
Hey everyone, 

I was wondering if anyone has advice on what to calculate in the EECS major GPA since (from what I can tell) it's not clearly defined by the CoE. For example, should I be including all classes that appear on the degree worksheet? For my situation, it would be disadvantageous to include specifically the Physics 7 series, and since my other EECS classes don't really depend on that knowledge I was wondering if it would okay to not include those grades in my calculation. Any advice? Thanks!

(For reference, I'm calculating this for graduate school applications.)

-Anonymous
history.subject: Calculating EECS major GPA
